title: Choosing the Right Lens for Event Photography
author: Neil Smith
excerpt: Prime vs. zoom, fast apertures, and practical ranges you’ll actually use when time is tight.
summary: Prime vs. zoom, fast apertures, and practical ranges you’ll actually use when time is tight.
content: When you’re moving quickly at an event, you want glass that balances reach, speed, and weight. A 24–70mm f/2.8 covers most of the day. If light drops, a 35mm or 50mm prime at f/1.8 can save ISO and keep noise down. The key is knowing your venue flow and packing to that reality.

title: How We Plan a Shoot: Brief to Delivery
author: Neil Smith
excerpt: A simple, repeatable plan—from discovery and shot lists to backups and handoff.
summary: A simple, repeatable plan—from discovery and shot lists to backups and handoff.
content: Every shoot starts with outcomes. We define the audience, channels, and usage first, then build a shot list that fits the deliverables. We timebox setup, coverage, and contingency. After the shoot: offload to redundant storage, cull, and deliver rough cuts for feedback.

title: Lighting Basics That Make Everything Look Better
author: Neil Smith
excerpt: Soften, raise, and angle your key—then balance practicals. Small changes, big difference.
summary: Soften, raise, and angle your key—then balance practicals. Small changes, big difference.
content: Start with a soft key source just above eye level, angled 30–45°. Flag spill, then let practicals set the mood. For portraits, add a gentle fill from the opposite side and a subtle hair light to separate subject from background.

title: Editing Workflow Basics for Fast Turnarounds
author: Neil Smith
excerpt: Ingest → backup → cull → grade → export. Save hours with a predictable pipeline.
summary: Ingest → backup → cull → grade → export. Save hours with a predictable pipeline.
content: Ingest to a project template with consistent folder names. Keep proxies and originals cleanly separated. Cull quickly with flags, then grade using saved looks. Export to target platforms with baked-in loudness or color profiles to avoid re-exporting later.

title: What to Include in a Service Request
author: Neil Smith
excerpt: Goals, audience, usage, timing, and a rough budget help us quote accurately and quickly.
summary: Goals, audience, usage, timing, and a rough budget help us quote accurately and quickly.
content: Clear goals focus creative choices. Include deadlines, locations, access constraints, and any brand references. Usage drives licensing—list platforms you need. A rough budget tells us how to scope efficiently.

title: Video Formats Explained: When to Use Which
author: Neil Smith
excerpt: H.264 for web, ProRes for editing, HEVC/AV1 for small files—choose based on where it plays.
summary: H.264 for web, ProRes for editing, HEVC/AV1 for small files—choose based on where it plays.
content: For web and social, H.264 (MP4) offers broad compatibility. For editing, lightly compressed mezzanine formats like ProRes or DNxHR preserve quality. HEVC and AV1 are efficient but may need fallbacks depending on the platform.

title: Responsive Images Primer: AVIF, WebP, and srcset
author: Neil Smith
excerpt: Use modern formats with sizes and DPR-aware srcset to boost speed without losing quality.
summary: Use modern formats with sizes and DPR-aware srcset to boost speed without losing quality.
content: Start with AVIF/WebP fallbacks, then define `srcset` densities (1x/2x) and width breakpoints. Always set width/height to prevent layout shift, and lazy-load below-the-fold images.

title: Security Headers: A Plain-English Guide
author: Neil Smith
excerpt: HSTS, CSP, and friends—what they do and why they matter to real users.
summary: HSTS, CSP, and friends—what they do and why they matter to real users.
content: Even small sites benefit from sane defaults: HTTPS only (HSTS), a conservative Content-Security-Policy, and X-Frame-Options. Start in report-only mode, then enforce once you’re confident.

title: Accessibility Wins: Small Tweaks, Big Impact
author: Neil Smith
excerpt: Keyboard focus, labels, and contrast checks improve UX for everyone—not just screen readers.
summary: Keyboard focus, labels, and contrast checks improve UX for everyone—not just screen readers.
content: Start with visible focus styling and label every control. Use semantic HTML and check color contrast. Test with a keyboard and a screen reader for the most common journeys.

title: Performance Quick Wins for Small Sites
author: Neil Smith
excerpt: From cache headers to image discipline—easy steps that make sites feel snappy.
summary: From cache headers to image discipline—easy steps that make sites feel snappy.
content: Add sensible cache headers, compress assets, and defer non-critical JS. Optimize hero images and use responsive sizes. Measure with Lighthouse, then iterate.
